subs.text: @trekonomics I published an anthology of "stories" about the Holocaust, compiled by a team of Holocaust educators. As I recall, the authors were generally if not exclusively survivors.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics I published an anthology of "stories" about the Holocaust, compiled by a team of Holocaust educators. As I recall, the authors were generally if not exclusively survivors.

subs.text: @trekonomics The educators felt that stories made for better education than other genres.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics The educators felt that stories made for better education than other genres.

subs.text: @trekonomics Upcoming is a translation of a volume of stories written in Yiddish and published in Poland in the 50s by someone who spent the war as a partisan in the woods.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics Upcoming is a translation of a volume of stories written in Yiddish and published in Poland in the 50s by someone who spent the war as a partisan in the woods.

subs.text: @trekonomics Not all of the stories could reflect first-hand experience. But I assume those that don't reflect first-hand conversations with the participants.
subs.rawText: @trekonomics Not all of the stories could reflect first-hand experience. But I assume those that don't reflect first-hand conversations with the participants.

subs.text: @trekonomics Conversely, I have an editor friend who works on memoirs by survivors. One essential task she performs is fact-checking the "memories" against the historical record.
